title: 105_hr3164
content:
The Act titled "Hydrographic Services Improvement Act of 1998" includes definitions for key terms. The "Hydrographic Services Improvement Act of 1998" defines key terms such as Administrator, Administration, hydrographic data, and hydrographic services related to bathymetric, geodetic, and tide information. The "Hydrographic Services Improvement Act of 1998" covers the production of nautical charts, databases, and other products from hydrographic data, development of nautical information systems, and related activities. It also defines the term "Act of 1947" as the legislation outlining the functions and duties of the Coast and Geodetic Survey. SEC. 3. FUNCTIONS OF THE ADMINISTRATOR. The Administrator is responsible for acquiring hydrographic data, setting standards for data and services, ensuring comprehensive coverage, maintaining a national database, providing services in accessible formats, and collaborating with other federal agencies. The Administrator, in cooperation with other Federal agencies, sets international standards for hydrographic data and services. They aim to fulfill requirements through contracts with private sector entities and have the authority to procure vessels, equipment, and technologies for safe navigation and data acquisition. They can also enter into agreements with qualified entities for these purposes. The Administrator, in cooperation with other Federal agencies, sets international standards for hydrographic data and services. They aim to fulfill requirements through contracts with private sector entities for data acquisition and hydrographic services. Contracts for data acquisition must comply with the Federal Property and Administrative Services Act of 1949. Additionally, they have the authority to design and install Physical Oceanographic Real-Time Systems for navigation safety and efficiency. SEC. 4. QUALITY ASSURANCE PROGRAM. The term "hydrographic product" refers to products containing hydrographic data. The Administrator can develop a quality assurance program to certify compliant products and charge a fee for certification. The fee must not exceed the costs of the quality assurance process. The Government of the United States is not liable for any negligence in producing certified hydrographic products. A Hydrographic Services Account is established to receive fees for certification and other amounts as provided by law. The Hydrographic Services Account receives fees for certification and other amounts as provided by law. Fees collected are deposited to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration account. No fees can be spent without appropriations Acts. The Administrator cannot establish new fees or increase existing fees for hydrographic services without authorization. The Administrator cannot establish new fees or increase existing fees for hydrographic services without authorization. SEC. 5. OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE OF PHYSICAL OCEANOGRAPHIC REAL-TIME SYSTEMS. The Administrator cannot design or install new systems without a local sponsor or Federal agency agreeing to cover operating costs. Existing systems will cease operation if no agreement is reached by specified dates. SEC. 6. REPORTS. The Administrator must report to Congress within 6 months on a plan to increase contracting with the private sector for photogrammetric and remote sensing services related to hydrographic data acquisition. The report should assess which services performed by the National Ocean Service can be adequately done by private-sector entities. The Administrator must report to Congress within 6 months on the status of implementing real-time tide and current data systems in US ports, safety and efficiency needs that could be met by these systems, and a plan to increase contracting with private-sector entities for services by fiscal year 2003. The Administrator must report to Congress within 6 months on a plan to maintain Federal expertise in hydrographic services after decommissioning existing vessels, including evaluating necessary capacity, personnel, and equipment. The Administrator must report to Congress within 6 months on a plan for decommissioning existing survey vessels and maintaining Federal expertise in hydrographic services, including estimated costs. SEC. 7. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Authorization of appropriations for nautical mapping, charting, and hydrographic surveys under the Act of 1947. $33-37 million allocated for mapping and charting functions for fiscal years 1999-2003, and $33-41 million for hydrographic surveys for the same period. The Administration's survey vessels are allocated funds for geodetic functions and tide/current measurements under the Act of 1947. $20-22 million is designated for geodetic functions for fiscal year 1999 and subsequent years, while $22.5 million is allocated for tide/current measurements for fiscal years 1999-2003. Additionally, funds are authorized for a national quality control system and real-time data measurement systems. SEC. 8. COMPLIANCE WITH BUY AMERICAN ACT.

No funds authorized by this Act can be spent unless the entity agrees to comply with the Buy American Act.

SEC. 9. SENSE OF THE CONGRESS; REQUIREMENT REGARDING NOTICE.

Entities receiving financial assistance under this Act should purchase American-made equipment and products. The Secretary of Commerce must provide recipients with a notice about this requirement. SEC. 10. PROHIBITION OF CONTRACTS.

If a court or Federal agency determines that a person falsely labeled a product as "Made in America" when it was not, that person will be ineligible for any contracts funded by this Act.
